<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TECH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/24/how-facebook-stumbled-in-india-its-largest-market?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
How Facebook Stumbled In Its Biggest Market
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/24/how-facebook-stumbled-in-india-its-largest-market?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg shake hands" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/4e6e3c93aa659dcfa5fb026d4e76173f7c5f992f-1024x704.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg shake hands (SUSANA BATES/AFP via Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">More people use Facebook’s platforms in India than in any other country—over 340 million are on Facebook and almost 400 million use its messaging service, WhatsApp. Leaked <a href="https://apnews.com/article/coronavirus-pandemic-technology-business-media-religion-74175aa6f2cb50fc6fb1aedda11b2c6c?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">internal research</a> shows that the company has struggled to root out misinformation and abusive content in the country, fueling violent ethnic conflicts.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">One example: In 2019, FB employees set up a dummy account to explore how a new user in India experiences Facebook.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>When violence erupted in the disputed region of Kashmir, leading to the death of more than 40 Indian soldiers, the account’s feed was flooded with a “near constant barrage of polarizing nationalist content, misinformation, and violence and gore,” one employee wrote.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“I’ve seen more images of dead people in the past three weeks than I’ve seen in my entire life total,” a researcher said of the experiment.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This episode and others like it reveal that for all the criticism directed at Facebook for fomenting polarization in the US...its effects on the political climate in lower-income countries, such as India, is <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/10/24/india-facebook-misinformation-hate-speech/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">far worse</a>, the WaPo writes.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">One challenge for moderating content in India is the sheer number of languages used there. The country has 22 officially recognized languages, but Facebook’s AI systems are trained on just five, which makes flagging harmful content much more difficult and the process becomes more reliant on human reviewers. Facebook told the WaPo it’s increased its investment in moderation over the past two years in countries most vulnerable to conflict and violence.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0"><strong style="color:#000">For Facebook, winter is coming</strong></h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you opened up a newspaper over the weekend, then you probably saw a barrage of stories bashing Facebook. Roughly <a href="https://www.axios.com/clegg-facebook-exec-bad-headlines-whistleblower-documents-9acbf8c8-94c1-4ce6-97f0-0cf03b1bc7c0.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">two dozen outlets</a> have published—or plan to publish—a batch of reports based on documents leaked by whistleblower Frances Haugen.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And as it gears up to report its Q3 earnings today, the company is prepping for more blowback. “We need to steel ourselves for more bad headlines in the coming days, I’m afraid,” Facebook VP of Global Affairs Nick Clegg wrote in a Saturday post to staffers obtained by Axios.</p>
</div>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RETAIL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/24/despite-inflation-consumers-keep-spending?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Clear Eyes, Full Wallets, Can't Lose
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/24/despite-inflation-consumers-keep-spending?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Will Ferrel leaving a store and pumping his fist " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=270 src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-10-24/image-3ccb2ce8166b04c74fa9d23f0a98c59f3913f8f9-400x161-gif/giphy(8).gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Will Ferrel leaving a store and pumping his fist " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-10-24/image-3ccb2ce8166b04c74fa9d23f0a98c59f3913f8f9-400x161-gif/giphy(8).gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">You may be grumbling to your friends about inflation, but higher prices haven’t stopped you from shelling out $11 for a burrito, <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-companies-bet-shoppers-will-keep-paying-higher-prices-11635067802?mod=hp_lead_pos2" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reports the WSJ</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Recent statements from companies that have hiked prices show that even in this inflationary environment, many consumers are in a cushy enough position to grin and bear it.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A few examples:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The allure of a Chiptole burrito, even if a few nickels more expensive, has never been stronger. Higher menu prices helped the restaurant chain </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/chipotles-profit-rises-11-as-chains-burritos-get-pricier-11634850263?mod=article_inline" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">more than double</a></span><span> its net income last quarter from a year ago.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>P&G, the maker of Tide and Old Spice, will launch its third round of price increases over the next few months...and expects profitably to increase.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Perhaps this statement from the CFO of supermarket giant Kroger sums it up best: “We’ve been very comfortable with our ability to pass on the increases that we’ve seen at this point.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>The resilience of the American consumer has been one of the most surprising outcomes of the pandemic, and its imbalance with available inventory is one of the main drivers of supply chain bottlenecks. Americans just <a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2021/10/stop-shopping-global-supply-chain-shipping-delays/620465/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">won’t stop buying stuff</a>.</p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SOCIAL MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/24/trump-s-new-media-venture-is-the-newest-meme-stock?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Trump's Social Media Company Is the Latest Meme Stock
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/24/trump-s-new-media-venture-is-the-newest-meme-stock?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Former President Trump waving at a rally" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/0c78c27f7e90ebc7638bdfc0ad1580d06a6198b6-1024x683.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Aaron P. Bernstein/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Former President Trump announced he was creating a <a href="https://apnews.com/article/donald-trump-technology-business-media-social-media-bcd42b4a669557cbc074ba4aac53ca59?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">new media venture</a> last Wednesday and since then, the share price of a company that’s taking it public has been on a ride reminiscent of GameStop and AMC in the early days of 2021.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Digital World Acquisition Corp., which is a SPAC (special purpose acquisition company), soared from $9.96/share before the announcement to $94.20—a jump of 846%. Even in the wild world of SPACs, that’s an unhinged rally, and it reflects heightened interest among retail traders looking to make a quick buck.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The implied value of the new company is now </span><span><a href="https://finance.yahoo.com/news/trump-tech-spac-could-him-121500317.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">more than $8.2 billion</a></span><span>. Since Trump appears to own more than 50% of the enterprise, according to SEC docs, it would make him the richest he’s ever been.</span>
</li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quick reminder: </strong>A SPAC is a shell company that’s formed with the goal of acquiring other companies and taking them public. It’s been an increasingly popular way for companies to list their shares on the public market—WeWork just went public via SPAC last week.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What is Trump’s new company? </strong>It’s a social media platform called “Truth Social” and...<a href="https://www.axios.com/trump-social-network-social-spac-11ae24f9-1774-4b31-946a-e5ab1b5b017e.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">that’s about all we know</a>. No CEO was mentioned, and neither were any financial metrics. A press release said the company is planning a launch early next year.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">“This appears to be a shell company buying a shell company,” Axios’s dealmaking reporter Dan Primack wrote.</p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GRAB BAG
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/24/key-performance-indicators-october-25?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Key Performance Indicators
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/24/key-performance-indicators-october-25?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt='A sign in California reads "standing water, reduce speed" amid deluge' style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/8475d3e4cec476d2deb03ccd5626d75ad6768fdc-1024x686.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Justin Sullivan/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>Last week, Sacramento, CA, recorded its <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/weather/2021/10/24/california-atmospheric-river-soaked/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">first 0.01 inches of rain</a> since March 19, amounting to a record 222 days without precipitation. That changed in a big way as a potentially historic “atmospheric river” pummels Northern California with rain and snow.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>“Hyperinflation is going to change everything. It’s happening.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Jack Dorsey, the CEO of Twitter and Square, tweeted this <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/23/twitter-and-square-ceo-jack-dorsey-says-hyperinflation-will-happen-soon-in-the-us-and-the-world.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">semi-apocalyptic take</a> around higher prices. Many economists replied that even though prices are rising faster than expected, hyperinflation—which has only occurred dozens of times throughout history and destroys economies—is not happening in the US.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quick read: </strong>Four theories of why Hollywood started making sequels in 1999. (<a href="https://twitter.com/DKThomp/status/1451936568025960455?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Derek Thompson</a>)</p>
</div>

</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/24/the-week-ahead?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">

The Week Ahead

</h1>

<img alt="Artists paint a mural ahead of the COP26 summit in Glasgow " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/9c3612f665de8a7c9c5e472ec3482e0a64f46e86-1024x681.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Artists paint a mural ahead of the COP26 summit in Glasgow (Jeff J Mitchell/Getty Images)</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Climate summit: </strong>The COP26 climate summit hosted by the UN will kick off in Glasgow, Scotland, on Sunday. COP26’s president, Alok Sharma, has called it a “make or break” moment in the battle to confront climate change.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Earnings: </strong>The motherload of earnings reports is <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/22/earnings-alphabet-apple-results-could-test-stocks-recent-rally.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">dropping this week</a>—30% of all S&P 500 companies will tell investors how they fared in Q3, including Amazon, Alphabet, Microsoft, Apple, Coca-Cola, Boeing, McDonald’s and many more. Analysts expect these reports to test the stock market’s latest rally.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Vaccines, but rated G: </strong>An FDA panel will debate on Tuesday whether to recommend authorization to give Pfizer’s vaccine to kids age 5–11. They could start receiving shots in the first two weeks of November, Dr. Fauci said.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Everything else…</strong></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Speaking of Halloween, it’s happening on Sunday.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Facebook could announce its new name at its Connect Conference on Thursday.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The World Series, pitting the Houston Astros against the Atlanta Braves, starts Tuesday.</span></li>
</ul>
</div>

style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eIndian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg shake hands (SUSANA BATES/AFP via Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eMore people use Facebook’s platforms in India than in any other country—over 340 million are on Facebook and almost 400 million use its messaging service, WhatsApp. Leaked \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/coronavirus-pandemic-technology-business-media-religion-74175aa6f2cb50fc6fb1aedda11b2c6c?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003einternal research\u003c/a\u003e shows that the company has struggled to root out misinformation and abusive content in the country, fueling violent ethnic conflicts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOne example: In 2019, FB employees set up a dummy account to explore how a new user in India experiences Facebook.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWhen violence erupted in the disputed region of Kashmir, leading to the death of more than 40 Indian soldiers, the account’s feed was flooded with a “near constant barrage of polarizing nationalist content, misinformation, and violence and gore,” one employee wrote.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“I’ve seen more images of dead people in the past three weeks than I’ve seen in my entire life total,” a researcher said of the experiment.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThis episode and others like it reveal that for all the criticism directed at Facebook for fomenting polarization in the US...its effects on the political climate in lower-income countries, such as India, is \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/10/24/india-facebook-misinformation-hate-speech/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efar worse\u003c/a\u003e, the WaPo writes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOne challenge for moderating content in India is the sheer number of languages used there. The country has 22 officially recognized languages, but Facebook’s AI systems are trained on just five, which makes flagging harmful content much more difficult and the process becomes more reliant on human reviewers. Facebook told the WaPo it’s increased its investment in moderation over the past two years in countries most vulnerable to conflict and violence.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eFor Facebook, winter is coming\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf you opened up a newspaper over the weekend, then you probably saw a barrage of stories bashing Facebook. Roughly \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/clegg-facebook-exec-bad-headlines-whistleblower-documents-9acbf8c8-94c1-4ce6-97f0-0cf03b1bc7c0.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etwo dozen outlets\u003c/a\u003e have published—or plan to publish—a batch of reports based on documents leaked by whistleblower Frances Haugen.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnd as it gears up to report its Q3 earnings today, the company is prepping for more blowback. “We need to steel ourselves for more bad headlines in the coming days, I’m afraid,” Facebook VP of Global Affairs Nick Clegg wrote in a Saturday post to staffers obtained by Axios.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYou may be grumbling to your friends about inflation, but higher prices haven’t stopped you from shelling out $11 for a burrito, \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-companies-bet-shoppers-will-keep-paying-higher-prices-11635067802?mod=hp_lead_pos2\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereports the WSJ\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eRecent statements from companies that have hiked prices show that even in this inflationary environment, many consumers are in a cushy enough position to grin and bear it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eA few examples:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe allure of a Chiptole burrito, even if a few nickels more expensive, has never been stronger. Higher menu prices helped the restaurant chain \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/chipotles-profit-rises-11-as-chains-burritos-get-pricier-11634850263?mod=article_inline\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emore than double\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e its net income last quarter from a year ago.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eP\u0026G, the maker of Tide and Old Spice, will launch its third round of price increases over the next few months...and expects profitably to increase.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePerhaps this statement from the CFO of supermarket giant Kroger sums it up best: “We’ve been very comfortable with our ability to pass on the increases that we’ve seen at this point.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eThe resilience of the American consumer has been one of the most surprising outcomes of the pandemic, and its imbalance with available inventory is one of the main drivers of supply chain bottlenecks. Americans just \u003ca href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2021/10/stop-shopping-global-supply-chain-shipping-delays/620465/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewon’t stop buying stuff\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eAaron P. Bernstein/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFormer President Trump announced he was creating a \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/donald-trump-technology-business-media-social-media-bcd42b4a669557cbc074ba4aac53ca59?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enew media venture\u003c/a\u003e last Wednesday and since then, the share price of a company that’s taking it public has been on a ride reminiscent of GameStop and AMC in the early days of 2021.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eDigital World Acquisition Corp., which is a SPAC (special purpose acquisition company), soared from $9.96/share before the announcement to $94.20—a jump of 846%. Even in the wild world of SPACs, that’s an unhinged rally, and it reflects heightened interest among retail traders looking to make a quick buck.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe implied value of the new company is now \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://finance.yahoo.com/news/trump-tech-spac-could-him-121500317.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emore than $8.2 billion\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. Since Trump appears to own more than 50% of the enterprise, according to SEC docs, it would make him the richest he’s ever been.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eQuick reminder: \u003c/strong\u003eA SPAC is a shell company that’s formed with the goal of acquiring other companies and taking them public. It’s been an increasingly popular way for companies to list their shares on the public market—WeWork just went public via SPAC last week.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat is Trump’s new company? \u003c/strong\u003eIt’s a social media platform called “Truth Social” and...\u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/trump-social-network-social-spac-11ae24f9-1774-4b31-946a-e5ab1b5b017e.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethat’s about all we know\u003c/a\u003e. No CEO was mentioned, and neither were any financial metrics. A press release said the company is planning a launch early next year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e“This appears to be a shell company buying
